CAS Key Laboratory of Low-Carbon Conversion Science and Engineering, Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences Shanghai 201203 PR China Selective conversion of syngas to olefins has aroused extensive attention while some challenges still existed such as high CO2 selectivity. Herein, a series of hydrophobic FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 (y represents SiO2 weight percent of the catalyst) catalysts with various SiO2 shell content were synthesized for Fischer-Tropsch to olefins (FTO). During the activation process, high hydrophobic SiO2-coating content catalysts suppressed the reduction/carburization of iron species to iron carbide. During FTO reaction, iron carbide of low hydrophobic SiO2-coating content catalysts was re-oxidized while it was stabilized for high hydrophobic SiO2-coating content catalysts. The trade-off among CO2, CH4 selectivity and SiO2-coating content was reflected as an increasing trend relationship, while olefins selectivity exhibited a decreasing trend. Additionally, a desirable hydrophobic SiO2-coating (8.2 wt%) catalyst apparently suppressed CO2 formation (4.7 C%) with high olefins selectivity (54.6 C%) at CO conversion of 50.7%. This study provides an efficient approach to inhibit CO2 formation of Fe-based FTO catalyst. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Fe-based catalyst Hydrophobic Core-shell structure Olefins Fischer-Tropsch synthesis 1 Introduction Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) plays a vital role in producing non-petroleum fuels and chemicals from alternative carbon resources including coal, natural gas, biomass or solid waste [1–3]. Olefins are the key feedstocks for high value-added chemical products, such as polymers, plastics and detergent. At present, the research on catalysts for Fischer-Tropsch to olefins (FTO) mainly focuses on transition metal elements, such as iron and cobalt. Fe-based catalyst was widely applied in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis due to its low price, high activity, poison resistance and flexibility [4–6]. However, the active sites of Fe-based catalysts were controversial due to multiple iron phases present during Fischer-Tropsch reaction, such as α-Fe, Fe3O4, χ-Fe5C2, ε-Fe2C, Fe7C3 and θ-Fe3C [7]. Xu et al. [8] found that ε-Fe2C showed promising activity of RQ Fe catalyst. Yang et al. [9] synthesized χ-Fe5C2 nanoparticles with high intrinsic activity. Chang et al. [10] reported the Fe7C3 had highly intrinsic activity in the medium-temperature Fischer−Tropsch reaction conditions. The FTS process usually produces hydrocarbons, meanwhile it inevitably generates a large quantity of byproducts such as water and CO2 [11,12]. All of the commercial FTS refineries have units to purify water [13] but the separation of CO2 requires high energy consumption [14]. Although iron carbides are generally accepted as the active phase in FTS, the iron-based catalysts inevitably release CO2 during FTS reaction [12]. The findings in literature on CO2 selectivity are summarized in Table S1 indicating the H2/CO ratio, reaction pressure, reaction temperature, and CO conversion. For example, de Jong et al. [15] reported Na/S modified Fe/CNF for FTO which attained 52% lower olefins selectivity with a high CO2 selectivity of 42% at 340 °C. Liu et al. [16] observed that manganese-modified Fe3O4 microsphere catalyst formed θ-Fe3C in FTO with ~60% lower olefins selectivity and 30~40% CO2 selectivity. Generally, the production of substantial CO2 is a common issue for metal carbide/oxide catalysts in CO hydrogenation ascribed to the same catalyst also acts as active site for water-gas-shift (WGS) reaction. It is still a great challenge to suppress CO2 formation and enhance the carbon efficiency in FTO process. Controlling the composition of iron carbide is a beneficial strategy to hinder the formation of CO2. For example, Wang et al. [17] synthesized pure phase ε(´)-Fe2C which exhibited low CO2 selectivity at 235 °C. Lyu et al. [18] synthesized Fe2C@graphene with low CO2 selectivity under realistic FT conditions (300 °C). Apart from controlling the composition of iron carbide, the other effective strategy to suppress the CO2 selectivity is to design hydrophobic core-shell structure catalyst. Yu et al. [19] synthesized a methyl modified core-shell Fe2O3 @SiO2 catalysts with ~5% CO2 selectivity. Yan et al. [20] synthesized core-shell Fe3O4 @SiO2-PFTS and reduced CO2 selectivity from 44% to 12%. Lin et al. [21] designed silica-coated CoMn-based catalyst for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis to olefins (58.8 C%) with low CO2 selectivity (15.1 C%). Ding et al. [22] reported hydrophobic core-shell FeMn@SiO2 could suppress the selectivity of C1 products (CO2 and CH4) to less than 22.5% with high olefins selectivity. However, controlling the composition of iron carbide was limited by the relative low temperature (< 300 °C) because active iron carbide (Fe2C) was not stable in FTO reaction condition (300–350 °C). The phase transformation of the hydrophobic core-shell structure of Fe-based FTO catalyst was complex and indistinct, and the effect of SiO2 shell was still elusive. Hence, it is essential to investigate the relationship between catalytic performance and catalyst phase compositions during the activation and FTO reaction process of the catalysts with varied hydrophobic SiO2 shell content. Herein, a series of controllable hydrophobic SiO2 shell on FeMnOx @SiO2 catalysts were synthesized through hydrothermal method, Stöber method, and silylation reaction route. The SiO2 shell was used to bridge FeMnOx core and hydrophobic groups of –CH3 to acquire a highly hydrophobic surface of FeMnOx catalysts. The hydrophobic surface via methyl modification could suppress the re-adsorption of water and hinder remarkably the water gas shift (WGS) activity to reduce CO2 emission. Multiple characterization techniques such as N2 adsorption/desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), Raman spectroscopy, scanning transmission electron microscope - energy dispersive spectroscopy (STEM-EDS) elemental mapping, and Mössbauer spectroscopy were applied to reveal the phase transformation and structure-performance relationship of the hydrophobic FeMnOx @SiO2-y-(CH3)3 (y represents SiO2 weight percent of the catalyst) catalysts for FTO process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Scheme 1 shows the schematic illustration of four-step synthesis of hydrophobic core-shell FeMnOx @SiO2 catalyst, including synthesis of FeMnOx precursor, synthesis of FeMnOx @SiO2 using stöber method,synthesis of methyl-modified FeMnOx @SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalysts (y represents the weight percent of SiO2 shell), and synthesis of α-Fe/FexC-MnOx @SiO2-y-(CH3)3 via activation process which included the hydrogen reduction and subsequently syngas carburization process. The specific synthetic route of the hydrophobic core-shell FeMnOx @SiO2 catalyst are shown according to the following Eqs. (1–4). (1) F eCl 3 • 6 H 2 O + Mn Cl 2 • 4 H 2 O → C H 3 COONa / EG FeMn O x (2) Tetraethyl orthosilicate ( TEO S ) → N H 3 ∙ H 2 O SiO 2 (3) ≡Si–OH + Cl–Si(CH3)3 (TMCS) → ≡Si–O–Si(CH3)3+HCl (4) FeMn O x @Si O 2 − y − CH 3 3 → Reduction / Carburization α − Fe / Fe x C − Mn O x @Si O 2 − y − CH 3 3 2.1.1 Synthesis of FeMnOx precursor The catalyst precursor FeMnOx was synthesized by a solvothermal method as reported by literature [23]. Firstly, a certain amount of FeCl3•6H2O (AR, Aladdin) and MnCl2•4H2O (AR, Aladdin) were dissolved in 168 mL ethylene glycol (EG) and stirred for 30 min, then added 19.2 g anhydrous sodium acetate (AR, Aladdin) and stirred vigorously for 1 h. Finally, the solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (500 mL), maintained at 200 ºC for 8 h and then cooled down to room temperature. The as-prepared FeMnOx precursor was separated by a magnet, washed with anhydrous ethanol and deionized water for several times, and put into vacuum at 60 ºC for 10 h. The synthesis of Fe3O4 catalyst adopted the similar method with that of FeMnOx. 2.1.2 Synthesis of FeMnOx@SiO2-y microspheres The synthesis of FeMnOx@SiO2-y refers to stöber method. First, 2 g FeMnOx precursor was dispersed in 640 mL solution (VCH3CH2OH:VH2O = 4:1) by ultrasonic dispersion. Then the solution was transferred to a three-necked flask (2000 mL) with a stirring paddle at a speed of 300 rpm/min. Next, 12 mL NH3·H2O (25–28 wt%) was slowly dropped to the flask, then a certain amount of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was added to the mixed solution with a pipette gun and kept stirring for 6 h. The products were washed by ethanol and deionized water for several times and under vacuum drying overnight. The resulting catalysts were denoted as FeMnOx@SiO2-y, where y represents the SiO2 weight percent of the catalysts measured by XRF. 2.1.3 Synthesis of FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalysts 2 g FeMnOx @SiO2-y was dispersed in 16 mL n-hexane by ultrasonic dispersion. Then, 4 mL chlorotrimethylsilane (TMCS) was added to the mixed solution and kept ultrasonic bath for 2 h. The resulting product (FeMnOx @SiO2-y-(CH3)3) was washed by n-hexane and dried under vacuum for 10 h. 2.1.4 Synthesis of α-Fe/FexC-MnOx@SiO2-(CH3)3 catalysts The activation process of FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalysts was a two-step process to prepare α-Fe/FexC-MnOx @SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalysts. Firstly, 1 g FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalyst and 2 g quartz were mixed evenly and loaded into the fixed bed reactor. Then, the catalyst was reduced under pure H2 flow for 24 h at 350 ºC, 6000 h-1, and 0.1 MPa. Finally, the H2 flow was switched to syngas (H2/CO = 1) for catalyst carburization at the same condition for 24 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations Elemental analysis was carried out by using an X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (Rigaku ZSX PrimusⅡ). About 100 mg samples were pressed into thin slices to determine the content of each element of the fresh catalysts. The textural properties of the fresh catalysts were measured at − 196 ºC by a N2 adsorption/desorption method on a Micromeritics 3Flex instrument. Prior to each test, the catalyst (~200 mg) was degassed at 300 ºC for 6 h. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was used to calculate the specific surface area. Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method was applied to calculate the total pore volume and average pore size. Catalyst crystallite phases were identified by a Rigaku Ultima IV X–ray diffractometer (XRD) instrument with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) operated under 40 kV and 40 mA. The scanning range was set from 5º to 90º and the scanning speed was set to 1º/min. The XRD patterns were compared with the JCPDS standard cards to determine the bulk crystalline structures. The average crystallite size of Fe3O4/FeMnOx in the different fresh catalysts was estimated from the Scherrer formula of Eq. (5) using the most intense reflection at 2θ = 35.45º, where d is the average crystallite sizes of Fe3O4/FeMnOx, λ = 0.154056 nm is the wavelength of the target Cu Kα, θ B is the Bragg angle. B is the line broadening by reference to a standard so that B 2 = B M 2 − B S 2 , where B M is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the diffracted plane of the most intense reflection at 2θ = 35.45º, and B S is the full width at half maximum (FWHM: 0.1º 2θ) of the standard material in radians. (5) d = 0.9 λ B cos θ B × 180 o π Surface chemical groups of catalysts were analyzed by a Fourier transform microscopic infrared spectrometer (Thermo Scientific, Nicolet iN10) in the range of 400–4000 cm-1. After the background was collected, the spectra of sample were collected with a transmission mode. The high-resolution and scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping measurements were performed on a FEI-TALOS-F200X electron microscope with 200 kV accelerating voltage. The samples were dispersed in ethanol for 20 min with ultrasonic treatment, and then deposited onto formvar-coated 300 mesh copper grids for observation. Raman spectra of the catalysts were obtained on a Thermo Scientific DXR 2xi Raman Microscope with an EMCCD detector and a 532 nm Ar ion laser. The operation conditions were 2 mW, 0.5 s and 100 scans. Room temperature Mössbauer spectra were recorded by Wissel accelerated Mössbauer spectrometer moving in the mode of constant accelerations which was equipped with 57Co(Pd) irradiation source. The least square method was used to fit the spectra, and the sub-spectra were fitted by Lorenz curve. The specific iron phase components were identified based on their isomer shift (IS), quadruple splitting (QS) and magnetic hyperfine fields (Hhf). The magnetic hyperfine fields were calibrated by an α-Fe foil with the field of 330 kOe at room temperature. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation After the activation process, the catalysts were in situ cooled to 180 ºC and then was tested at the reaction condition of 320 ºC, 2 MPa and 4000 h-1 with a heating rate of 1 ºC/min. The GHSV range of 4000–84000 h-1 was applied for catalytic performance under similar CO conversion. The syngas mixture (H2/CO=2, 3% N2 used as internal standard) was used for catalytic performance evaluation. The effluent gas, after passing through a hot trap (120 ºC) and a cold trap (0 ºC), was analyzed online by a Shimadzu gas chromatograph (GC-2014) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The H2, N2, CO, CH4 and CO2 were analyzed by thermal conductivity detector (TCD) with a carbon molecular sieve column. The lower hydrocarbons (C1-C7) were analyzed by hydrogen flame ionization detector (FID) with a KCl-modified alumina capillary column. The aqueous products, liquid oil products and solid wax products which were collected from cold trap and hot trap was off-line analyzed by Shimadzu GC. The aqueous products were analyzed by TCD equipped with two Porapack Q columns for H2O and methanol, and C1-C5 oxygenates was analyzed by an FID. The oil products were analyzed by FID with a HP-1 column. The wax was dissolved in CS2 and analyzed by FID with an MXT-1 column. The catalytic performance data after 12 h of steady-state reaction based on gas, liquid, and wax compositions were typically applied for discussion. The test run for each catalyst was repeated 3 times, and the statistical analysis was performed to obtain the mean value and standard deviations of catalytic performance data. Mass, carbon, and oxygen balances were performed based on the total inlet/outlet flows, gas composition analysis, liquid and wax product weight and composition. Mass, carbon, and oxygen balances were calculated and kept higher than 95%. CO conversion was calculated according to Eq. (6), where F in and F out (mol/s) are the total molar flow rates of the reactor inlet and outlet gas, respectively, where X (i),in and X (i),out are the molar fraction of component i in the reactor inlet gas and outlet gas. (6) CO conversion ( % ) = F in X CO , in − F out X CO , out F in X CO , in × 100 The product selectivity was calculated using Eq. (7), where n j represents the number of carbon atoms involved in product j, and X j denotes the molar fraction of product j. (7) Product selectivity ( % ) = n j F out X j F in X CO , in − F out X CO , out × 100 The chain growth probability α of catalysts was calculated by using Anderson–Schulz–Flory (ASF) distribution function according to Eq. (8): (8) ln w n n = nln α + ln ( 1 − α ) 2 α where w n represents the mass fraction of products with n carbon numbers. From the slope of the plot of ln( w n n ) against n, the value of α can be obtained. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterizations 3.1.1 Characterization of the fresh catalysts To quantify the weight percent of the SiO2 shell in the fresh catalysts, XRF technique was used to analyze the samples. Table 1 shows the XRF elements analysis results of the fresh catalysts based on the weight percentage. The Mn element content is about 5 (wt%), and Si element content of the fresh catalysts gradually increases, corresponding to the increase of SiO2 content as 8.2 (wt%), 9.8 (wt%), 11.7 (wt%), 13.1 (wt%) and 16.3 (wt%), respectively. Fig. 1 shows the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the fresh catalysts. The Fe3O4 and FeMnOx catalysts exhibited type-IV isotherm with H3 hysteresis loop, indicated the existence of mesoporous structures composed of gaps. After the incorporation of SiO2-coating, the hydrophobic catalysts also showed type-IV isotherm which was similar as Fe3O4 and FeMnOx catalysts, indicating that SiO2-coating had little influence on the intrinsic pore structure of Fe-Mn composite oxide. The pore size distribution of Fe3O4 exhibited mesopores around 4–40 nm, while pore size distribution of other catalysts exhibited mesopores around 2–6 nm. Besides, the mesopores around 2–6 nm showed a descending trend with improving the content of SiO2-coating, indicating that SiO2 shell on the surface of catalysts decreased the mesoporous size [24]. Table 2 shows the textural properties of the fresh catalysts. The BET surface area of Fe3O4 and FeMnOx catalysts were 18.8 m2/g and 77.2 m2/g, respectively. The BET surface area of low SiO2-coating content hydrophobic catalysts decreased slightly while BET surface area improved slightly in high SiO2-coating content. Besides, BET surface area and volume of microspores increased slightly indicating that mesopore SiO2 existed on the surface of catalysts. The average pore size decreased slightly with improving the content of SiO2-coating, which was probably attributed to the reduction of mesopores due to FeMnOx nanoparticles aggregated in high SiO2-coating [24]. From the XRD patterns, the fresh FeMnOx ( Fig. 2a) and FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalysts (Fig. 2b) catalyst mainly composed of Fe3O4 (JCPDS # 75–0033) and Mn3O4 (JCPDS # 13–0162) crystallite phases. The characteristic diffraction peaks related to MnOx species (MnO, Mn2O3, MnO2, etc.) were not observed in the XRD patterns (Fig. 2a and b). Thus, MnOx may be presented as Mn3O4 in the fresh catalyst due to the characteristic peaks of Fe3O4 overlaid with Mn3O4 stemming from their similar spinel type structures. Typically, no peaks related to SiO2 were observed due to the formation of amorphous phase of SiO2 coated on the FeMnOx catalyst. Besides, the introduction of SiO2 shell did not affect the crystallite structure of the catalysts. As shown in Table S2, the calculated average crystallite sizes the fresh Fe3O4 and FeMnOx catalysts are 14.3 nm and 9.8 nm, respectively. The calculated average crystallite size of FeMnOx for the FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 (y = 8.2, 9.8, 11.7, 13.1 and 16.3, respectively) are around 9.7–11.7 nm (Table S2). HRTEM images confirm that the fresh Fe3O4 catalyst is microsphere structure (Fig. S1), the lattice fringes of 2.09, 2.42, and 2.53 Å corresponds to the Fe3O4 (400), (222), and (311) planes, respectively. Surface chemical groups of hydrophobic catalysts were characterized by FT-IR. All of the fresh catalysts exhibit a wide band near 3340 cm-1 and 1620 cm-1 which are assigned to O–H stretching and H–O–H bending vibrations of free and adsorbed water molecules [25] (Fig. 2c). The peaks at 790 cm-1 and 1064 cm-1 are attributed to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibration of SiO2 [26], and the peak at 940 cm-1 is ascribed to the stretching vibration of Si–OH [25]. The adsorption band at 1210 cm-1 is assigned to symmetric deformation vibration of Si–CH3 bond [27]. The absorption bands at 2960 cm-1 and 2900 cm-1 are corresponding to C–H asymmetric and symmetric stretches of –CH3 group [28,29]. Besides，the bending vibration at 1430 cm-1 stems from –CH3 group of all fresh catalysts [28]. FT-IR spectra shows little differences related to SiO2 loading of the fresh hydrophobic FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 (y = 8.2, 9.8, 11.7, 13.1, and 16.3) catalysts (Fig. 2c). FT-IR spectra suggested that SiO2 shell and hydrophobic groups were successfully introduced onto the surface of the fresh catalysts. Fig. 2d shows the Raman spectra of FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalysts. All of the fresh catalysts possessed characteristic peaks of Fe3O4 (T2 g(1) mode at 193 cm-1, T2 g (2) mode at 300 cm-1, T2g(3) at 540 cm-1, A1g mode at 660 cm-1) [30–34] and characteristic peaks of carbonaceous species (D band at 1400 cm-1) [35], usually assigned to disordered amorphous carbonaceous species. Compared with Raman spectrum of Fe3O4 (Fig. S2), FeMnOx @SiO2-y-(CH3)3 and FeMnOx catalysts showed a typical peak at 651 cm-1, 360 cm-1 and 318 cm-1 [36] which was assigned to the stretching mode of Mn3O4. The peak at 600 cm-1 was assigned to the stretching mode of MnO [36,37] attributing to the formation of FeMnOx via the solvothermal method. STEM-EDS elemental mapping of the fresh FeMnOx catalyst (Fig. S3) shows the microsphere structure with homogeneous distribution of Fe, Mn, O, and C elements. The spatial distribution of different elements (Fe, Mn, Si, C, O) of the fresh FeMnOx @SiO2-y-(CH3)3 (y = 8.2, 9.8, 11.7, 13.1, and 16.3, respectively) catalysts were also investigated by STEM-EDS elemental mapping ( Fig. 3 and Fig. S4). The Fe and Mn elements are uniformly distributed as a microsphere and Si element is distributed as a shell surrounding the microsphere, indicating that the synthetic catalysts are core-shell structure (Fig. 3 and Fig. S4). Additionally, the SiO2 shell thickness increased as the increase of the SiO2-coating content (Fig. 3 and Fig. S4). Fig. 4 shows the water-droplet contact angle of the fresh catalysts. After the hydrophobic modification, the contact angles of the FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalysts are greater than 90º (Fig. 4a-e), indicating that the hydrophobic groups (–CH3) effectively improve the hydrophobicity of the catalyst surface via TMCS modification. However, the contact angles of FeMnOx (Fig. 4f) and Fe3O4 (Fig. S5) are only 73º and 46º (less than 90º), respectively, indicating their hydrophilic surfaces. 3.1.2 Characterization of the catalysts after activation Fig. 5 shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts after activation. After activation, the Fe3O4 and FeMnOx catalysts were mainly transformed into χ-Fe5C2 (Fig. 5a). Fig. S6 shows the HRTEM images of Fe3O4 catalyst after activation, the lattice fringe of 2.21 Å corresponds to the χ-Fe5C2 ( 1 ̅ 12) plane. The crystallite phase of FeMnOx@SiO2-8.2-(CH3)3 is χ-Fe5C2 with a small amount of Fe3O4 (Fig. 5b), coupled with characteristic peaks at 2θ= 26.7º, 29.5ºand 61.3º for diluted quartz mixed with catalyst during the activation process. As increasing the hydrophobic SiO2 shell content, the crystallite phases of FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 (y = 9.8, 11.7, 13.1 and 16.3) are mainly α-Fe with a small amount of iron carbide (Fig. 5c), suggesting that the hydrophobic SiO2 shell may hinder the activation process of the FeMnOx @SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalysts. The typical peaks of MnO (645 cm-1 and 547 cm-1) (Fig. 5d) are also observed in the Raman spectra [36]. STEM-EDS elemental mapping of the FeMnOx catalyst after activation (Fig. S7) shows the phase segregation between Fe and Mn elements. The spatial distribution of different elements (Fe, Mn, Si, C, O) of the fresh FeMnOx @SiO2-y-(CH3)3 (y = 8.2, 9.8, 11.7, 13.1, and 16.3, respectively) catalysts were also investigated by STEM-EDS elemental mapping ( Fig. 6 and Fig. S8). After the activation process, the hydrophobic core-shell catalyst maintained the stable microsphere core-shell structure due to the SiO2 shell confinement effect. Additionally, Mn species tended to maintain stable microsphere structure while Fe species shrank as a core. However, the microsphere structure of the fresh FeMnOx catalyst (Fig. S3) finally collapsed after activation (Fig. S7). Volynova et al. [38] found that MnO could hardly reduce to Mn0 unless temperature up to 1280 ºC, suggesting MnOx was more difficult to be reduced than Fe3O4. Therefore, MnO was stable after activation. The iron phase evolution of FeMnOx @SiO2-y-(CH3)3 during the activation process firstly initiated from iron oxide to α-Fe, then a small amount of α-Fe was further carburized to form iron carbide. The specific iron phase compositions of the catalysts after activation were further identified by Mössbauer spectroscopy ( Fig. 7 and Fig. S9). The spectra demonstrated complex magnetic interactions owing to the presence of multiple magnetic phases. Mössbauer spectra fitting parameters of various phases and their relative contributions to spectral absorption areas are summarized in Table 3 and Table S3. Percentage areas can be transformed into percent content of the various iron phases, assuming the similar Mössbauer efficiency (recoil-free fraction) for all iron phases. All of the Mössbauer spectra could be fitted with the combination of sextets and/or doublets. These doublets were assigned to α-Fe or the Fe2+ and Fe3+ super-paramagnetic (spm) ions on the non-cubic sites with smaller crystallite diameters [39]. The sextets were attributed to either Fe3O4 or iron carbides, and could be identified based on their hyperfine parameters (Hhf) [40,41]. As listed in Table 3 and Table S3, χ-Fe5C2 and Fe3O4 can be fitted with sextets and α-Fe can be fitted with doublet. The subspectra with IS (0.20–0.40 mm/s) and Hhf (110–250 kOe) correspond to three different sites of stoichiometric iron carbide (χ-Fe5C2) [40]. Taking the FeMnOx@SiO2-8.2-(CH3)3 catalyst after activation for example, the Hhf of 211, 185 and 112.5 kOe of sextets are assigned to three different sites of χ-Fe5C2 [42]. The subspectra with Hhf (490–520 kOe) are attributed to the Fe3+ sites, while those Hhf (300–480 kOe) are resulted from the Fe2+ sites of ferrimagnetic Fe3O4 phases [40,43]. The subspectrum with IS= 0 mm/s and Hhf (~330 kOe) is usually associated with α-Fe [44]. Taking the FeMnOx@SiO2-9.8-(CH3)3 catalyst after activation for example, the Hhf of ~330.7 kOe of doublet was assigned to α-Fe. With the increase of hydrophobic SiO2 shell content, the χ-Fe5C2 content decreased from 76.7% (FeMnOx@SiO2-8.2-(CH3)3) to 10–16% (FeMnOx @SiO2-y-(CH3)3, y > 8.2). Thus, the addition of hydrophobic SiO2 shell inhibited the carburization of iron species during the activation process. 3.1.3 Characterization of the spent catalysts Fig. 8 shows the XRD patterns of the spent catalysts (after FTO reaction). Compared with the catalysts after activation (Fig. 5b and c), the bulk phase of the spent catalysts was obviously different. The intensity of iron carbide of the FeMnOx @SiO2-8.2-(CH3)3 catalyst became weak, meanwhile the intensity of iron carbide of FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 (y > 8.2) was strengthened whereas the intensity of α-Fe displayed a contrary trend. Meanwhile, the Fe2SiO4 (JCPDS # 76–0512) phase was formed in all the spent catalysts (Fig. 8). Silica-coating interacted with Fe species by the formation of Fe–O–Si structure, which further converted into Fe2SiO4 during FTO reaction [40]. The interaction greatly disturbed the electronic structure of Fe atoms in iron oxide phases thereby inhibiting the activation of the catalysts [40]. Besides, the formation of Fe3O4 resulted from iron species oxidized by water vapor. The spatial distribution of different elements (Fe, Mn, Si, C, O) over the spent FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 (y = 8.2, 9.8, 11.7, 13.1, and 16.3, respectively) catalysts were studied by STEM-EDS elemental mapping ( Fig. 9 and Fig. S10). After the FTO reaction, the hydrophobic core-shell catalysts almost maintained the stable microsphere core-shell structure owing to the SiO2 shell confinement effect (Fig. 9 and Fig. S10). However, the STEM-EDS elemental mapping image indicated that the spent FeMnOx catalyst exhibited the severe phase separation of Fe and Mn species (Fig. S11). The iron phase compositions of the spent catalysts were further identified by Mössbauer spectroscopy ( Fig. 10). The specific relative contributions to spectral absorption areas with fitted Mössbauer parameters are listed in Table 4. The Mössbauer spectra of hydrophobic catalysts were fitted doublets and sextets, representing spm/Fe2SiO4 and χ-Fe5C2. The sextets corresponded to Fe3O4 or χ-Fe5C2 as the above-mentioned of the catalysts after activation (Fig. 7 and Table 3). Taking the FeMnOx@SiO2-11.7-(CH3)3 catalyst for example, the doublets with IS = 1.15 mm/s and QS = 2.79 mm/s are generally associated with Fe2SiO4 [45,46] and Fe2+ or Fe3+ super-paramagnetic (spm) ions (IS = 1.05 mm/s and QS = 1.51 mm/s) are also fitted with doublets [47]. For the spent FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalysts, there is a decrease trend between iron carbide content and SiO2 content (Table 4). After FTO reaction, the χ-Fe5C2 content of low SiO2-coating catalyst (y = 8.2) decreased to 49.6%. However, the χ-Fe5C2 content of high SiO2-coating catalysts (y > 8.2) slightly enhanced in comparison with the catalysts after activation. Besides, Fe3O4 content of all the spent catalysts increased, indicating that Fe species could be further oxidized by water vapor generated during FTO reaction. 3.2 Catalytic performances 3.2.1 The effects of hydrophobic SiO2 shell on the catalytic activity To investigate SiO2-coating effect on the activity of the catalysts, the catalytic performances of FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalysts with different SiO2-coating content were firstly compared under the same reaction conditions. The CO conversion of Fe3O4 and FeMnOx catalysts are the highest (~98%). As shown in Table 5, CO conversion shows a descending tendency with increasing SiO2-coating content. The CO conversion of FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalysts decrease dramatically from 76.3% to 42.6% corresponding to SiO2-coating content from 8.2% to 16.3%. Clearly, the addition of the SiO2-coatings on the catalysts significantly decreases catalytic activity and the similar inhibiting effect of SiO2 shell was reported by Xu et al. [24]. FeMnOx exhibited lower CH4 selectivity compared with Fe3O4 owing to Mn suppressed the formation of CH4 [48]. Besides, the olefins selectivity improves obviously while CO2 selectivity decrease apparently over the hydrophobic catalysts compared to Fe3O4 and FeMnOx catalysts, especially the FeMnOx@SiO2-9.8-(CH3)3 has the maximum olefins selectivity (50.1%) and FeMnOx@SiO2-16.3-(CH3)3 possesses the minimum CO2 selectivity (10.8%). 3.2.2 The effects of hydrophobic SiO2 shell on the product selectivity It is well established that in FTS the product selectivity varies with CO conversion, especially olefins selectivity, and olefin/paraffin ratio, and CO2 selectivity, as reported by Thybaut et al. [49,50] and Davis et al. [51]. Thus, the catalytic performances of the catalysts with different SiO2-coating content were carried out under similar CO conversion level (~48 ± 3%) for further discussion. As shown in Table 6, the CO2 selectivity of Fe3O4 is the highest, indicating its high WGS reaction activity. Fe3O4 also owes the highest CH4 selectivity (22.9%). Generally, high WGS reaction activity often resulted in high local H2/CO on the catalyst surface that was favorable to generate CH4 [19]. However, CO2 selectivity decreases from 30.6% (FeMnOx catalyst) to 17% (Fe3O4 catalyst), in agreement with the previous result reported by Ma et al. [52]. Besides, FeMnOx catalyst suppressed the formation of CH4 and improved the selectivity towards olefins in comparison with Fe3O4 catalyst, which was ascribed to Mn species could improve the catalyst surface basicity and suppress the secondary hydrogenation of olefins [53–55]. Compared with Fe3O4 and FeMnOx catalysts, CO2 selectivity of the low SiO2-coating hydrophobic catalysts decreased apparently. However, CO2 selectivity of the hydrophobic SiO2-coating catalysts shows an increase trend as increasing the SiO2 content (Table 6). The CO2 selectivity of FeMnOx@SiO2-8.2-(CH)3 and FeMnOx@SiO2-9.8-(CH)3 are 4.7% and 6.6%, respectively. However, CO2 selectivity further increased as improving the SiO2-coating content. For example, the CO2 selectivity of FeMnOx@SiO2-13.1-(CH)3 and FeMnOx@SiO2-16.3-(CH)3 are 12.2% and 17.2%, respectively. Besides, the trade-off between CH4 selectivity and hydrophobic SiO2-coating content was reflected as a positive relationship (Table 6). Hydrophobic SiO2-coating could prevent the re-adsorption of water generated during FTO reaction [19,28], and thus suppressed the WGS reaction. Meanwhile, the high SiO2-coating confined the water being removed out promptly, which could increase the local water partial pressure, resulting in the oxidation of iron carbide [56]. The hydrophobic SiO2-coating of the catalysts also limit the diffusion of reactants during FTO reaction as increasing the SiO2-coating content [57]. Therefore, high SiO2-coating content promoted the WGS reaction [58,59] and boosted the local H2/CO ratio, thereby enhancing the CO2 and CH4 selectivity. Furthermore, the olefins selectivity of hydrophobic SiO2-coating catalysts increased apparently compared to Fe3O4 and FeMnOx catalysts. The hydrophobic modification inhibited the WGS reaction, which was beneficial to reduce the capability of hydrogenation [60]. However, with regards to the hydrophobic SiO2-coating catalysts, the olefins selectivity decreases and CO2 selectivity simultaneously increases as increasing the SiO2-coating content, indicating that the WGS capability enhanced in high SiO2-coating so as to reduce the olefins selectivity. The FeMnOx catalyst exhibited similar CO2 selectivity but its olefins selectivity was lower compared to FeMnOx@SiO2-16.3-(CH)3 catalyst. The phases segregation between the Mn species and Fe species over the FeMnOx catalyst after reaction was obvious (Fig. S11). Owing to the confinement effect of SiO2-coating (Fig. 9 and Fig. S10), MnOx was seemingly moving towards the silica shell and maintained the stable microsphere structure over the spent hydrophobic SiO2-coating catalyst. A desirable amount of SiO2 shell content (8.2%) could suppress the secondary hydrogenation and improve the olefins selectivity, which corresponded to the C3H6-pulse hydrogenation results (Figs. S12–14, Table S4). Besides, the ASF chain growth probability (α) of FeMnOx @SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalysts exhibited a slightly decreasing trend ( Fig. 11). The ASF chain growth probability (α) of Fe3O4 catalyst is 0.55 (Fig. S15). The carbon number distribution of hydrocarbons was preferable toward light hydrocarbons as increasing the hydrophobic SiO2 shell content (Fig. 11b-f), and the similar result was reported by Xu et al. [24]. 3.3 The structure-performance relationship To investigate the phase transformation during the activation process, the bulk phase after hydrogen reduction (without syngas carburization) was also characterized by XRD (Fig. S16). The bulk phase of Fe3O4 and FeMnOx catalysts (Fig. S16a) is mainly α-Fe with a small amount of FeO, indicating that MnOx suppressed the reduction of FeO to α-Fe [61,62]. The phase composition of FeMnOx @SiO2-8.2-(CH3)3 after hydrogen reduction is mainly α-Fe with a small amount of Fe3O4 (Fig. S16b). Besides, with regard to the hydrophobic SiO2-coating catalyst after hydrogen reduction (Fig. S16b), the intensity of the diffraction peaks of α-Fe decreases and Fe3O4 increases with increasing the SiO2-coating content. Previous work reported that adding SiO2 restrained the reduction of Fe species [40,63] and MnOx could stabilize the phase of FeO [61,62], indicating that SiO2 and MnOx could jointly retard the removal of bulk oxygen in the catalysts [55]. Thus, Fe species of the hydrophobic FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalysts were difficultly reduced to α-Fe by hydrogen with increasing the SiO2-coating content. During syngas carburization process, the iron oxide and α-Fe was further reduced/carburized to χ-Fe5C2. The Fe3O4 and FeMnOx catalysts could be completely carburized to χ-Fe5C2 (Fig. 5a, Fig. S9 and Table S3). The main phase of low SiO2-coating catalyst (y = 8.2) is χ-Fe5C2 (Fig. 5b, Fig. 7 and Table 3), while the main phase of high SiO2-coating catalysts (y > 8.2) is α-Fe (Fig. 5c, Fig. 7 and Table 3), suggesting that the carburization is significantly influenced by SiO2-coating content. The small mesopores (~2–4 nm) (Table 1) in high SiO2-coating catalysts limited the diffusion of CO [24,57,58], formed the hydrogen-rich environment of the core-shell catalysts [64] and reduced the local CO concentration, resulting in dramatically lowering the carbon chemical potential (μC) [65]. Additionally, owing to the confinement effect of SiO2-coating (Fig. 6 and Fig. S8), MnOx was seemingly moving towards the silica shell and maintained the stable microsphere structure over hydrophobic SiO2-coating catalysts during activation, which probably reduced the porosity and resulted in a hindrance of the carburization process. Thus, the SiO2-coating significantly inhibited the carburization of Fe species during the activation process. Fig. 12 shows the detailed iron phase compositions (based on Mössbauer spectra fitted area) of the catalysts between after activation and after reaction to investigate the phase transformation (Tables 3 and 4). Compared with Fe3O4 and FeMnOx catalyst, χ-Fe5C2 content of the hydrophobic SiO2-coating catalysts significantly decreased, indicating that SiO2-coating hindered the carburization of Fe species during the activation process. Low SiO2-coating content catalyst had a slight effect on the carburization, and the χ-Fe5C2 content of FeMnOx@SiO2-8.2-(CH3)3 was 76.7%. The χ-Fe5C2 content (< 20%) of FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 (y > 8.2) decreased sharply as increasing the SiO2-coating content (Fig. 12). After FTO reaction, the χ-Fe5C2 content of low SiO2-coating catalyst (y = 8.2) greatly decreased corresponding to the increase of Fe3O4 content. The χ-Fe5C2 content over high SiO2-coating catalysts (y > 8.2) increased slightly though some oxidation iron phase existed. Meanwhile the α-Fe content of the FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 (y > 8.2) after reaction decreased sharply, indicating that Fe species were further carburized to χ-Fe5C2 (Fig. 12). Obviously, high SiO2-coating content inhibited the iron carbide from reoxidation by water vapor. Sirimanothan et al. [66] and Suo et al. [40] also reported that SiO2 had a stabilizing effect on iron carbide. Thus, high hydrophobic SiO2-coating could stabilize the iron carbide of the catalysts during FTO reaction. The hydrophobic SiO2 shell not only influenced the phase transformation but also affected CO conversion and the product selectivity. χ-Fe5C2 was widely accepted as the active phase in Fe-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [67]. As shown in Fig. 13a, CO conversion demonstrates a descending tendency in accordance with the decrease of the χ-Fe5C2 content of the spent catalysts with improving the hydrophobic SiO2-coating content, owing to the χ-Fe5C2 active phase determines the catalytic activity. Although hydrophobic SiO2-coating could suppress the WGS reaction and significantly boost the olefins selectivity, CH4 and CO2 selectivity exhibits an increasing trend while olefins gradually decrease with increasing the hydrophobic SiO2-coating content (Fig. 13b). Besides, the hydrophobic SiO2-coating of the catalysts also affect the hydrogenation capability, the ratio of olefins/paraffins (O/P) descends in the medium SiO2-coating content (y = 9.8–13.1) (Fig. 13b) corresponding to C3H6-pulse hydrogenation results (Figs. S12–14, Table S4). Scheme 2 illustrates the mechanism of the hydrophobic core-shell FeMnOx@SiO2 catalysts reduce surface water vapor content to suppress WGS reaction for enhancing the olefins selectivity from FTO reaction. During FTO reaction, metallic α-Fe has high reactivity for CO dissociation [68], resulting in higher C coverage to form FexC or subsequently reacts with absorbed H* on the surface of α-Fe/FexC to form CxHy * . MnOx promoter could improve the catalyst surface basicity and suppress the secondary hydrogenation of olefins to enhance the olefins selectivity [52–54]. The O* species usually reacts to form byproduct (H2O/CO2) or oxygenates, while the hydrophobic SiO2 shell inhibits the re-adsorption of water vapor [19,22], thereby suppressing the WGS reaction to reduce the CO2 selectivity. 4 Conclusions In this study, the combined multiple characterization techniques (N2 adsorption/desorption, XRD, Raman spectroscopy, FT-IR, Mössbauer spectroscopy, STEM-EDS elemental mapping) were applied to investigate the bulk phase compositions of FeMn@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 catalysts with adjustable hydrophobic SiO2-coating during the activation and reaction process. During the activation process, low hydrophobic SiO2-coating catalysts had a slight effect on the reduction/carburization of iron species, while high hydrophobic SiO2-coating catalysts suppressed the reduction/carburization of iron species to iron carbide. During FTO reaction, iron carbide of low hydrophobic SiO2-coating catalysts was re-oxidized while the iron carbide of high hydrophobic SiO2-coating catalysts was stabilized. The hydrophobic SiO2-coating catalysts significantly hindered the formation of CO2 and improved the olefins selectivity. The trade-off among CO2 selectivity, CH4 selectivity and SiO2-coating content was reflected as an increasing trend relationship, while olefins selectivity exhibited a decreasing trend. A desirable hydrophobic SiO2 shell content (8.2 wt%) of the core-shell FeMnOx@SiO2-(CH3)3 catalyst could obtain a high olefins selectivity (~54.6%) and relatively low CO2 selectivity (~4.7%) at CO conversion of 50.7%. coredata.dc:description: Selective conversion of syngas to olefins has aroused extensive attention while some challenges still existed such as high CO2 selectivity. Herein, a series of hydrophobic FeMnOx@SiO2-y-(CH3)3 (y represents SiO2 weight percent of the catalyst) catalysts with various SiO2 shell content were synthesized for Fischer-Tropsch to olefins (FTO). During the activation process, high hydrophobic SiO2-coating content catalysts suppressed the reduction/carburization of iron species to iron carbide. During FTO reaction, iron carbide of low hydrophobic SiO2-coating content catalysts was re-oxidized while it was stabilized for high hydrophobic SiO2-coating content catalysts. The trade-off among CO2, CH4 selectivity and SiO2-coating content was reflected as an increasing trend relationship, while olefins selectivity exhibited a decreasing trend. Additionally, a desirable hydrophobic SiO2-coating (8.2 wt%) catalyst apparently suppressed CO2 formation (4.7 C%) with high olefins selectivity (54.6 C%) at CO conversion of 50.7%. This study provides an efficient approach to inhibit CO2 formation of Fe-based FTO catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Fischer-Trospch to olefins over hydrophobic FeMnOx@SiO2 catalysts: The effect of SiO2 shell content
